rows.principle_details: Diversification is key to agroecological transitions to ensure food security and nutrition while conserving, protecting and enhancing natural resources.

Sharing knowledge and creating connections between agro-ecosystems 
(plants, animals, ...) strengthens agriculture.
Enhanced resilience of people, communities and ecosystems is key to sustainable food and agricultural systems.
Innovative agroecological practices produce more using less external resources.
More recycling means agricultural production with lower economic and environmental costs.

Achieving sustainable human and agricultural development requires effective and responsible governance mechanisms that prioritise social well-being through solidarity and equity.

Closer ties between producers and consumers can protect rural livelihoods and strengthen communities.
By supporting healthy, diversified and culturally appropriate diets, agroecology contributes to food security and nutrition while maintaining the health of ecosystems.
